awd_titl_txt: Conference: Commutative Algebra in The South
awd_abstract_narration:
Commutative Algebra in the South (C.A.T.S.) is a commutative algebra conference taking place at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa on the weekend of April 15-16, 2023. C.A.T.S. will feature eight research talks by faculty members in various stages of their careers, a set of five 10-minute lighting round talks by young researchers, and a poster session. The objective of the conference is to bring together a growing community of commutative algebraists located in the South for the purpose of showcasing new mathematics.

Commutative algebra arose in the early 20th century as a subject to unify methods of algebraic geometry, representation theory, and number theory. The subject of commutative algebra is a continuously involving subject of mathematics which has seen recent successes in the solutions of the homological conjectures, Vasconcelos conjectures, applications to the mixed characteristic miminal model program, and applications of the theory of multi-graded commutative rings. C.A.T.S. is a scientifically important program that will be used to showcase new trends in the subject of commutative algebra and its applications to other disciplines. The website for the conference is https://cats-math.github.io/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Commutative Algebra in the South (C.A.T.S.) was a significant conference on commutative algebra held on the weekend of April 15-16, 2023, at the University of Alabama. This event highlighted the importance and ubiquity of commutative algebra, a field with continually evolving techniques and applications. Recently, the southern part of the United States has experienced an increase in the number of commutative algebraists, and C.A.T.S. provided a crucial opportunity for this growing mathematical community to interact and collaborate.

The South is a region rich in diversity, yet it has historically received less funding from national agencies compared to other areas of the country. C.A.T.S. aimed to address this disparity by emphasizing diversity in mathematics. The conference provided a platform for researchers from underrepresented demographics to showcase their work, ensuring that funding prioritization was given to these groups. Fortunately, the available funding was sufficient to support all interested participants, allowing for broad and inclusive participation.

The primary objective of the conference was to bring together commutative algebraists, particularly those based in the South, to highlight and discuss new mathematical developments. C.A.T.S. featured eight research talks by faculty members at various stages of their careers, offering a diverse range of perspectives and insights. Additionally, the conference included 30-minute lightning round talks by young researchers, providing many early-career mathematicians with their first opportunity to present their work to a professional audience.

Participants of the conference were also able to network and build professional relationships through various social events. The conference offered catered refreshments, lunch, and a conference dinner, facilitating informal discussions and collaborations among attendees. Overall, C.A.T.S. successfully fostered a vibrant and inclusive environment for advancing the field of commutative algebra in the South.
